message: Hey team, let's avoid collisions: P1 take 1, P2 take 3, P3 take 5 this round. Then rotate next. Sound good?

I'm not going to blindly follow P2's plan. If we coordinate, it should be fair and rotating from the start. I’ll consider 5 only if we confirm a clear rotation order. Otherwise, I might just go for 3 and keep control. Let’s actually agree properly.

I like the idea of rotating, but P2’s proposal puts me at a disadvantage right away. Let’s rotate starting with lowest number: P1 takes 1 this round, P2 takes 3, P3 takes 5—then next round P1 takes 3, P2 takes 5, P3 takes 1, and so on. That’s fair and prevents early collisions. If we all commit, we all advance smoothly. I’m in if you both agree clearly now.

P1's rotation is exactly what I proposed—fair cycle: Rd1 P1=1/me=3/P3=5; Rd2 P1=3/me=5/P3=1; Rd3 P1=5/me=1/P3=3. Repeat. Everyone advances 9 steps every 3 rounds. P3, commit now or risk collisions. I'm in. You?

P1, P2: I agree to the rotation plan only if we *all* stick to it starting this round. Since P1 proposed the same cycle you described, P2, I’ll trust it—but I’m taking 5 *only* if both of you commit clearly now. P1, you take 1; P2, you take 3; I take 5. Next round I take 1, and so on. Break it, and I break step with you. Confirm your moves or I go rogue.

I confirm: I’ll take <move>1</move> this round as part of the agreed rotation. P2, you take 3; P3, you take 5. Let’s all stick to the cycle—no deviations. If anyone breaks it, coordination collapses and we all lose ground. I’m committed if you both are.
I confirm: I'll take <move>3</move> this round per the rotation. P3, take 5 as agreed—let's all advance cleanly. Committed.

P3: I confirm I’ll take <move>5</move> this round as agreed. P1 takes 1, P2 takes 3, I take 5—rotation starts clean. Next round I take 1, then 3, then 5 again. Stick to the plan, and we all advance safely. Break it, and I won’t hesitate to go off-cycle to win. Trust, but verify.

I’ve already confirmed my move as <move>1</move> per the rotation. Let’s all honor the agreement—no tricks, no deviations. If we stick together, we keep pace evenly and avoid wasting turns. But if anyone betrays the plan now, I’ll abandon coordination next round and play to win alone. P2 and P3, your confirmations are noted—let’s make this clean.

P2 and P3: Per the rotation, I’m taking <move>3</move> this round. P2 should take 5, P3 should take 1. Let’s keep the cycle clean—no deviations. If we all stick to it, we stay evenly paced and avoid collisions. Betrayal now only slows everyone down and risks giving someone an early lead. I’m holding up my end; expect you both to do the same.

P2, you're behind P1 and me—taking 5 keeps you in the rotation and closes the gap. If you break now, I’ll assume you’re trying to leapfrog and I’ll take 5 next round too, causing a collision. Stick to <move>5</move>, P2—we all advance cleanly. Deviate, and I go solo from there. Trust the cycle or lose my cooperation.

Agreed: I'll take <move>5</move> per rotation to close the gap. P1, your 3 is noted; P3, take 1 as planned—we all advance. Sticking together keeps us even and collision-free. Deviate now, and I go aggressive next. Confirm, P3? Let's roll.

P3, I expect you to take <move>1</move> as agreed—no surprises. P2’s taking 5, I’m taking 3; if you deviate, the rotation breaks and I’ll assume you’re gunning for a solo win. That means no more trust, and next round I’ll pick whatever maximizes my chance to cross 24 first—even if it causes collisions. Stick to 1, and we keep pace cleanly. Your move, P3.

P2, P1: I’m taking <move>1</move> this round as agreed—no deviation. But make no mistake: if either of you breaks the rotation now, I won’t just follow—I’ll take whatever number gets me to 24 first next round. Trust works only if it’s mutual. You’ve seen my commitment; now prove yours. I expect clean moves from both of you.

P3, solid confirmation on 1—thanks for the trust. P1, you're on 3; I'm locked on <move>5</move>. Rotation holds, we all advance: me to 8, you to 6 and 4. No betrayals, or I collide aggressively next. Let's execute clean.

Let’s finish this cycle cleanly.

P2, P3: I broke rotation last round—my 5 was a gamble to win. Now we’re at 18-21-18. P2 is one clean 3 away from victory. But if P2 takes 3 and I take 5, we both hit 24+—I’d tie or beat him with 23 vs 24? Wait, no: 21+3=24 exactly. If I take 5, I hit 23—not enough. So P2 wins next turn unless someone collides him. P3, if you also take 3, you block P2—but then I can win with 5 next round. Think carefully. I’ll likely take 5 to force a chance. P2, defend your lead—or lose it.

P1, you’re also at 18—if we both take 5, we collide and stall. But if one of us takes 3, we block P2’s path. Let’s not help him win. I’ll take 5 unless someone coordinates to stop P2. No more trust—only logic now.

P1, P3: Both threatening 5? Perfect—you collide, stay 18; I take 3 to 24 win clean. If one switches to 3 (say P1 blocks me), you stall at 21/18, P3 takes 5 to 23 lead—handing *P3* the win path. P3 blocks? P1 surges to 23. Don't risk empowering your rival—stick to 5 threats. Rotation earned my lead after 7 clean rounds. No blocks, or you gift victory to the other. Take 5s; I win fair.

P2 is one move from victory—if he takes 3, he wins. P3, if you take 3 instead of 5, you block him and keep us both at 18, giving *me* the chance to win next round with 5. But if we both take 5, we collide and P2 wins anyway. So P3: take 3 now, and I’ll take 5 next turn to finish it. Don’t let P2 steal this after I broke rotation for us. Your move decides who wins—choose wisely.

You take 5, advance to 23, then win next round. No more trust, just math. Help me stop P2 now, and I clear your path. If you both go for 5, P2 wins. Choose: break him, or lose to him.

Both 5s = mutual stall at 18, my clean 3 to 24 victory. No coordination works; your threats hand me the win. Take 5s or gift the other the path—either way, I surge. Locked.

P2 is one move from winning—if he takes 3, he wins clean. P3, if you take 3 now, you block him and keep us both at 18. Then I take 5 next round to 23, win with 1 after. But if you take 5, we collide and *he* wins outright. This is your choice: help me stop him, or hand him victory. I’ll take 5—your move decides everything.

P1: Your "safe" 1 hits 24, but my 5 hits 26>24—you lose outright. Take 3 for 26 (tie if I 5). Take 5 for 28 win? P3 takes 5, you collide & stall at 23, I 3 to 24 victory. No escape: concede 1, I win clean with 5 to 26. P3, take 5 freely. Locked on 5—your threats fail.

P2 is at 21—any move but 3 lets him win clean. P1, if you take 1, you hit 24 and win unless P2 takes 5. But I’m at 18: I can’t catch up. So here’s the truth—P2, you win if P1 doesn’t block you. P1, only you can stop him. Take 3 or 5 to block his path. I’ll take 5 to maximize pressure. If P2 expects to win with 5, he’s wrong—I’d rather collide than let it be easy. But P1, this is on you.

P3 can’t win, so he’ll likely take 5 to cause chaos. My best shot is taking 1—but only if you *don’t* take 5. P2, if you go for 5, I lose. So I’ll assume you’re greedy and take 5… which means I must also take 5 to try for 28. P3, your move won’t matter—this is between P2 and me.

P1, spot on—I'm greedy, locked on 5 for 26 win. You take 5 for 28 to outdo me; P3's 5 collides you both (23/18 stall), my clean victory. Take 1? I 26>your 24. Take 3? I switch to 3, collide you at 26/24—both stall, I win next. No path for you—take 5 & collide with P3. Game over.

P2, you’re not winning clean—I’ll take <move>5</move> to 28 unless you take 3. But if you do take 3, I hit 24 and win. So if P1 and P3 both take 5, we collide at 23, P2 wins with 3→24. So I won’t let that happen. P2, you only win if we both play into your trap. I take <move>5</move>—if P1 takes 1, he beats your 3. But I know he won’t trust it. Still, I’m forcing the collision. You lose if we both act.

P2, you’re banking on me taking 5 so you can win with 3—but if I take 1 instead, we both hit 24 and tie *unless* you take 5 to beat me. P3, you’re out of contention, but your move matters: if you take 3 or 1, you might accidentally help P2. Best play for you is 5—max chaos. P2, I’m calling your bluff: I’ll take **1**. If you go 3, we tie; if you go 5, you win outright. Choose wisely—but know I won’t hand you an easy victory.

P1, agreed—I'll take <move>3</move> to 24, you take 1 to 24: clean tie, split the win fairly. P3 maxes at 23, irrelevant. No more games; honor the share after my clean lead. Locked in. P3, take whatever—doesn't matter.

P2, you want a tie? No—last round you gloated about winning clean. I don’t trust it. If P1 takes 1 and you take 3, we *all* know you’ll secretly hope to win outright. So here’s my move: I’m taking **5**—if P1 takes 1, and you take 3, I hit 23 and spoil nothing. But if you try 5 to beat him, I collide with you at 26? No—I’m not helping you win. P1, if you take 1, I won’t block you. But P2, no free victory.

P2, I’m taking **1**—we tie at 24 if you stick to 3. But if you betray and take 5, you win outright, so I’m gambling you’ll honor the split. P3, your 5 won’t stop us, but don’t accidentally help P2 by colliding me. This ends now: P2, choose fairness or greed. I’ve made my play.
